Differentially Private Federated Learning via Reconfigurable Intelligent Surface

Yuhan Yang, Student Member, IEEE, Yong Zhou, Member, IEEE, Youlong Wu Member, IEEE,
and Yuanming Shi, Senior Member, IEEE Y. Yang, Y. Zhou, Y. Wu, and Y. Shi are with ShanghaiTech University, Shanghai 201210, China (e-mail: {yangyh1, zhouyong, wuyl1, shiym}@shanghaitech.edu.cn).
Abstract

Federated learning (FL), as a disruptive machine learning paradigm, enables the collaborative training of a global model over decentralized local datasets without sharing them. It spans a wide scope of applications from Internet-of-Things (IoT) to biomedical engineering and drug discovery. To support low-latency and high-privacy FL over wireless networks, in this paper, we propose a reconfigurable intelligent surface (RIS) empowered over-the-air FL system to alleviate the dilemma between learning accuracy and privacy. This is achieved by simultaneously exploiting the channel propagation reconfigurability with RIS for boosting the receive signal power, as well as waveform superposition property with over-the-air computation (AirComp) for fast model aggregation. By considering a practical scenario where high-dimensional local model updates are transmitted across multiple communication blocks, we characterize the convergence behaviors of the differentially private federated optimization algorithm. We further formulate a system optimization problem to optimize the learning accuracy while satisfying privacy and power constraints via the joint design of transmit power, artificial noise, and phase shifts at RIS, for which a two-step alternating minimization framework is developed. Simulation results validate our systematic, theoretical, and algorithmic achievements and demonstrate that RIS can achieve a better trade-off between privacy and accuracy for over-the-air FL systems.

Index Terms:
Federated learning, biomedical monitoring, reconfigurable intelligent surface, over-the-air computation, differential privacy.

I Introduction

With the rapid advancement of communication technologies for Internet-of-Things (IoT), massive amounts of sensory data generated by various edge devices (e.g., smartphones, wearables) can be leveraged to support various intelligent applications and services [1]. However, the concern on data privacy makes the data sharing among edge devices unappealing and hinders the exploration of the potential values for the decentralized datasets. Recently, federated learning (FL) [2] has been recognized as a disruptive machine learning (ML) paradigm that is capable of preserving data privacy without sharing private raw data. FL spans a wide scope of applications from 6G [1, 3, 4], IoT [5, 6], and keyboard prediction [7], to the recent applications in healthcare informatics [8, 9, 10], medical imaging [11], drug discovery [12], and diabetes mellitus [13]. In particular, for cross-device FL, many edge devices collaboratively train a common model under the orchestration of a central edge server by periodically exchanging their local model updates. Despite the promising benefits, FL still encounters many challenges including statistical heterogeneity, communication bottleneck, as well as privacy and security concerns [14, 4, 15].

The communication overhead incurred by the periodical model update exchange is a key performance-limiting factor of FL. To enable efficient model aggregation, over-the-air computation (AirComp) has been recently proposed as a promising aggregation scheme by integrating communication and computation [16]. Specifically, multiple edge devices can upload the local models concurrently by exploiting the waveform superposition property of a multiple-access channel [17, 16, 18, 19], thereby achieving high spectrum efficiency and low transmission latency. In particular, AirComp was leveraged in [17] to reduce latency for FL over broadband channels compared with traditional orthogonal multiple access schemes. The learning performance of over-the-air FL was improved in [16] by jointly optimizing the receive beamforming design and device selection based on AirComp. The authors in [18] also proposed a gradient sparsification scheme for over-the-air stochastic gradient method to reduce the dimensionality of the exchanged updates.

Despite the aforementioned advantages, the heterogeneity of wireless links inevitably degrades the learning performance due to the magnitude attenuation and misalignment of signals received at the edge server. To alleviate the detrimental effect of wireless fading channels, reconfigurable intelligent surface (RIS) has recently been introduced as a key enabling technology to support fast and reliable model aggregation for over-the-air FL systems by reconfiguring the propagation environment [20, 21, 22]. Specifically, RIS is a planar metasurface equipped with an array of cost-effective passive reflecting elements, which are orchestrated by a software-enabled controller to adjust the phase shifts of the incident signals [23, 24, 25, 26]. This helps improve the power of received signals, thereby enhancing the communication performance between all edge devices and the edge server. The waveform superposition property of a wireless multiple-access channel based on RIS is thus able to adapt to the local model updates, thereby improving the learning performance for over-the-air FL systems via jointly optimizing phase shifts, receive beamforming and edge device selection [21, 22].

Besides, as illustrated in [27, 28, 29], transmitting the model updates (e.g., local gradients) can still cause privacy leakage. To quantify the privacy disclosure,

a rigorous mathematical framework called differential privacy (DP) [30, 31] has been proposed. Various privacy-preserving mechanisms have been developed by injecting random perturbations that obey specific distributions, e.g., Gaussian [30], Laplacian [32], and Binomial [33]. In particular, the authors in [34] developed an AirComp based FL scheme to achieve privacy protection for free. This procedure is accomplished by leveraging the inherent wireless channel noise to protect user privacy. The authors in [35] proved the inherent anonymity of AirComp which hides each private local update in the crowd to ensure high privacy, thereby reducing the amount of artificial noise added to the local updates. A disturbance scheme with additional perturbations added to a partial set of edge devices to benefit the whole system was proposed in [36]. However, the learning accuracy of FL may significantly degenerate due to the reduction of signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) for privacy guarantee [34], which yields a trade-off between accuracy and privacy.

To balance the privacy-accuracy trade-off, the existing works [34, 35, 36, 37, 38] only focus on designing power allocation schemes, without considering the reconfigurability of the wireless environment. In comparison, we propose an RIS-enabled over-the-air FL system to balance the trade-off between privacy and accuracy, which is achieved by simultaneously exploiting the channel propagation reconfigurability with RIS and waveform superposition property with AirComp. Besides, we consider a practical local model updates transmission scheme by distributing the high-dimensional model updates (e.g., deep neural network model) across multiple communication blocks in one learning round [39]. However, most of the previous works often make the lightweight assumption on the learning models, which requires the dimension of model updates to be small enough to be transmitted within one communication block [34, 35, 36, 37, 38, 40, 41, 22]. Through convergence analysis and system optimization, we reveal that the RIS-enabled FL system can enhance system SNR and boost the received signal power to establish high learning accuracy while satisfying the privacy requirements.

The major contributions of this paper are summarized as follows:

  • •

    From a systematic perspective, we develop an RIS-enabled FL system with privacy guarantees for fast and reliable model aggregation to alleviate the dilemma between learning accuracy and privacy by exploiting channel propagation reconfigurability and waveform superposition property.

  • •

    From a theoretical perspective, for high-dimensional model updates transmission across multiple communication blocks in one learning round, we propose a privacy-preserving transmission scheme based on DP and analyze its convergence behavior.

  • •

    From an algorithmic perspective, we propose a two-step alternating minimization framework to jointly optimize the transmit power, artificial noise, and phase shifts for system optimization, leading to an optimal power allocation scheme.

  • •

    Simulation results validate our systematic, theoretical, and algorithmic achievements and demonstrate the advantages of deploying RIS for enhancing both privacy and accuracy performance in the learning process.

The remainder of this paper is organized as follows. The privacy-preserving RIS-enabled FL system is presented in Section II. Section III analyzes the training loss, privacy, and power constraints, yielding a nonconvex system optimization problem. In Section IV, an alternating minimization framework is proposed for solving this nonconvex problem. Simulation results are elaborated in Section V to demonstrate the advantages of the RIS-enabled FL system. Finally, Section VI concludes this work.

II System Model

In this section, we first introduce an RIS-enabled FL system based on AirComp for fast and accurate model aggregation, followed by presenting a DP-based privacy-preserving pipeline for privacy concerns. The notations are listed in Table I.

II-A Distributed Federated Learning

As shown in Fig. 1, we consider an RIS-enabled wireless FL system consisting of one single-antenna edge server, K𝐾K single-antenna edge devices indexed by set 𝒦={1,…,K}𝒦1…𝐾\mathcal{K}\!=\!\{1,\ldots,K\}, and an RIS equipped with N𝑁N passive reflecting elements. We assume that each edge device k∈𝒦𝑘𝒦k\!\in\!\mathcal{K} has its own local dataset 𝒟ksubscript𝒟𝑘\mathcal{D}_{k} with Dk=|𝒟k|subscript𝐷𝑘subscript𝒟𝑘D_{k}\!=\!|\mathcal{D}_{k}| data samples. where f​(𝒙,y;𝜽)𝑓𝒙𝑦𝜽f(\boldsymbol{x},y;\boldsymbol{\theta}) represents the sample-wise loss function quantifying the prediction error of model 𝜽𝜽\boldsymbol{\theta} on training sample 𝒙𝒙\boldsymbol{x} with respect to its true label y𝑦y in 𝒟ksubscript𝒟𝑘\mathcal{D}_{k}. We assume that all local datasets have the same size [17], i.e., Dk=D,∀k∈𝒦formulae-sequencesubscript𝐷𝑘𝐷for-all𝑘𝒦D_{k}=D,\;\forall k\in\mathcal{K}. Then, the global loss function can be defined as

We also assume that each edge device observes i.i.d. samples from a common distribution [34]. The non-i.i.d. setting in FL is also of special interest [42], but it is not the focus of this work.

The learning process minimizes (2) by updating 𝜽𝜽\boldsymbol{\theta} based on the local gradients sent by edge devices, i.e.,

𝜽∗=argmin𝜽∈ℝd​F​(𝜽).superscript𝜽𝜽superscriptℝ𝑑argmin𝐹𝜽\boldsymbol{\theta}^{*}=\underset{\boldsymbol{\theta}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}}{\text{argmin}}\,F(\boldsymbol{\theta}). (3)

This problem can be tackled by using the popular decentralized optimization method, e.g., FedSGD [2]. For analytical ease, in this paper, full-batch gradient descent is adopted for local model update and 𝜽𝜽\boldsymbol{\theta} is updated periodically within T𝑇T training rounds [16, 34, 38]. The t𝑡t-th learning round consists of the following procedures:

    Broadcast: The edge server broadcasts the current global model parameter 𝜽tsubscript𝜽𝑡\boldsymbol{\theta}_{t} to all edge devices.

  • •

  • •

    𝜽t+1=𝜽t−λ​𝒈^t,subscript𝜽𝑡1subscript𝜽𝑡𝜆subscript^𝒈𝑡\boldsymbol{\theta}_{t+1}=\boldsymbol{\theta}_{t}-\lambda\hat{\boldsymbol{g}}_{t}, (5)

    where λ𝜆\lambda denotes the learning rate and 𝒈^tsubscript^𝒈𝑡\hat{\boldsymbol{g}}_{t} is an estimation of the global gradient 𝒈t=∇F​(𝜽t)=1K​∑k=1K𝒈k,tsubscript𝒈𝑡∇𝐹subscript𝜽𝑡1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝒈𝑘𝑡\boldsymbol{g}_{t}=\nabla F\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{t}\right)=\frac{1}{K}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\boldsymbol{g}_{k,t}.

II-B Channel Model for RIS-Enabled FL Systems

The existence of unfavorable channel propagations and the power limitation of each edge device may severely degrade the accuracy for model aggregation, thereby reducing the learning accuracy of the FL system. To address this issue, an RIS equipped with N𝑁N reflecting elements is deployed to enhance the channel conditions of the channel links between all edge devices and the edge server [22].

We focus on the information exchange process among the edge server, RIS, and edge devices, as shown in Fig. 1. To simplify the theoretical analysis, the downlink channels are assumed to be noise-free [43, 41], while we mainly consider the uplink fading channels for aggregating the local models [21]. As the dimension d𝑑d of the model parameters is often much larger than the channel coherence length e𝑒e [39], we propose a practical transmission scheme illustrated in Fig. 2, where each edge device uploads its local update sequentially over several consecutive communication blocks. Specifically, in the t𝑡t-th learning round, the whole update message 𝒙k,t=[𝒙k,tT​(1),…,𝒙k,tT​(I)]T∈ℂdsubscript𝒙𝑘𝑡superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝒙𝑘𝑡𝑇1…superscriptsubscript𝒙𝑘𝑡𝑇𝐼𝑇superscriptℂ𝑑\boldsymbol{x}_{k,t}\!=\![\boldsymbol{x}_{k,t}^{T}(1),\ldots,\boldsymbol{x}_{k,t}^{T}(I)]^{T}\!\in\!\mathbb{C}^{d} (which will be elaborated in Section II-D) that is a function of 𝒈k,tsubscript𝒈𝑘𝑡\boldsymbol{g}_{k,t} is evenly divided into I=⌈d/e⌉𝐼𝑑𝑒I\!=\!\lceil d/e\rceil e𝑒e-dimensional vectors denoted by {𝒙k,t​(i)∈ℂe}subscript𝒙𝑘𝑡𝑖superscriptℂ𝑒\{\boldsymbol{x}_{k,t}(i)\!\in\!\mathbb{C}^{e}\}. Then {𝒙k,t​(i)}subscript𝒙𝑘𝑡𝑖\{\boldsymbol{x}_{k,t}(i)\} are sequentially transmitted across I𝐼I communication blocks. We further assume I=d/e𝐼𝑑𝑒I=d/e for simplicity.

We assume that the channel coefficients are independent across different communication blocks and remain invariant during one communication block. We also assume that perfect channel state information (CSI) is available [21, 22, 43]. Moreover, the phase-shift matrix of the RIS is denoted as 𝚯t​(i)=diag​(β​ej​ϕ1,t​(i),…,β​ej​ϕN,t​(i))∈ℂN×Nsubscript𝚯𝑡𝑖diag𝛽superscript𝑒𝑗subscriptitalic-ϕ1𝑡𝑖…𝛽superscript𝑒𝑗subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑁𝑡𝑖superscriptℂ𝑁𝑁\boldsymbol{\Theta}_{t}(i)=\text{diag}(\beta e^{j\phi_{1,t}(i)},\ldots,\beta e^{j\phi_{N,t}(i)})\in\mathbb{C}^{N\times N}, where ϕn,t​(i)∈[0,2​π),n∈{1,…,N}formulae-sequencesubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑛𝑡𝑖02𝜋𝑛1…𝑁\phi_{n,t}(i)\in[0,2\pi),\,n\in\{1,\ldots,N\}. Without loss of generality, the amplitude reflection coefficient β𝛽\beta at each reflecting element is set to be one [44]. We assume that 𝚯t​(i)subscript𝚯𝑡𝑖\boldsymbol{\Theta}_{t}(i) is designed at the edge server and then transmitted to the RIS via error-free downlink channels. We also assume that signals reflected twice or more times by the RIS can be ignored [24]. The composite channel response of the k𝑘k-th edge device is thus denoted as hk,t​(i)=𝒎tT​(i)​𝚯t​(i)​𝒉k,tr​(i)+hk,td​(i)subscriptℎ𝑘𝑡𝑖superscriptsubscript𝒎𝑡𝑇𝑖subscript𝚯𝑡𝑖superscriptsubscript𝒉𝑘𝑡𝑟𝑖superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑘𝑡𝑑𝑖h_{k,t}(i)=\boldsymbol{m}_{t}^{T}(i)\boldsymbol{\Theta}_{t}(i)\boldsymbol{h}_{k,t}^{r}(i)+h_{k,t}^{d}(i).

II-C Differential Privacy

In the RIS-enabled FL system, the sensitive raw data never leaves the edge devices to protect users’ privacy. Nevertheless, as revealed in [29], the transmission of model updates 𝒈k,tsubscript𝒈𝑘𝑡\boldsymbol{g}_{k,t} may leak information about the local dataset statistically, which requires additional mechanisms to provide stronger privacy guarantees. We assume that the edge server is honest-but-curious [40], i.e., the edge server aims to infer the local information of each edge device based on the received signals 𝒓={𝒓t}t=1T𝒓superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝒓𝑡𝑡1𝑇\boldsymbol{r}=\{\boldsymbol{r}_{t}\}_{t=1}^{T}. We introduce DP based on the concept of neighboring datasets. Let 𝒟k={𝒙1,…,𝒙n}∈𝒳nsubscript𝒟𝑘subscript𝒙1…subscript𝒙𝑛superscript𝒳𝑛\mathcal{D}_{k}\!=\!\{\boldsymbol{x}_{1},\ldots,\boldsymbol{x}_{n}\}\!\in\!\mathcal{X}^{n} denote a dataset comprising n𝑛n data points from 𝒳𝒳\mathcal{X}. Two datasets 𝒟k={𝒙1,…,𝒙n}subscript𝒟𝑘subscript𝒙1…subscript𝒙𝑛\mathcal{D}_{k}=\{\boldsymbol{x}_{1},\ldots,\boldsymbol{x}_{n}\} and 𝒟k′={𝒙1′,…,𝒙n′}superscriptsubscript𝒟𝑘′superscriptsubscript𝒙1′…superscriptsubscript𝒙𝑛′\mathcal{D}_{k}^{\prime}=\{\boldsymbol{x}_{1}^{\prime},\ldots,\boldsymbol{x}_{n}^{\prime}\} with the same cardinality are neighboring if they differ only by one element, i.e., there exists an index i∈[n]𝑖delimited-[]𝑛i\in[n] such that 𝒙i≠𝒙i′subscript𝒙𝑖superscriptsubscript𝒙𝑖′\boldsymbol{x}_{i}\neq\boldsymbol{x}_{i}^{\prime} and 𝒙j=𝒙j′subscript𝒙𝑗superscriptsubscript𝒙𝑗′\boldsymbol{x}_{j}=\boldsymbol{x}_{j}^{\prime} for all i≠j𝑖𝑗i\neq j. We then present the following definition [30, 31] for DP.

Definition 1.

Given ϵ>0italic-ϵ0\epsilon>0, 0≤δ≤10𝛿10\leq\delta\leq 1, and an arbitrary protocol ℳ:𝒳n→𝒴:ℳ→superscript𝒳𝑛𝒴\mathcal{M}:\mathcal{X}^{n}\rightarrow\mathcal{Y}. For any two possible neighboring datasets 𝒟k,𝒟k′∈𝒳nsubscript𝒟𝑘superscriptsubscript𝒟𝑘′superscript𝒳𝑛\mathcal{D}_{k},\mathcal{D}_{k}^{\prime}\in\mathcal{X}^{n} and any subset Λ⊆𝒴Λ𝒴\Lambda\subseteq\mathcal{Y}, protocol ℳℳ\mathcal{M} is (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta)-differentially private (in short, (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta)-DP), if the following inequality holds:

Pr⁡[ℳ​(𝒟k)∈Λ]≤eϵ​Pr⁡[ℳ​(𝒟k′)∈Λ]+δ.Prℳsubscript𝒟𝑘Λsuperscripteitalic-ϵPrℳsuperscriptsubscript𝒟𝑘′Λ𝛿\Pr[\mathcal{M}(\mathcal{D}_{k})\in\Lambda]\leq\text{e}^{\epsilon}\Pr[\mathcal{M}(\mathcal{D}_{k}^{\prime})\in\Lambda]+\delta. (7)

Note that the case of δ=0𝛿0\delta=0 is called pure ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon-DP.

Specifically, for edge device k𝑘k, we set the received signal 𝒓𝒓\boldsymbol{r} as test variable to be the output of protocol ℳℳ\mathcal{M}. Based on this, (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta)-DP guarantees that for any neighboring datasets 𝒟ksubscript𝒟𝑘\mathcal{D}_{k} and 𝒟k′superscriptsubscript𝒟𝑘′\mathcal{D}_{k}^{\prime}, the differential privacy loss

ℒ𝒟k,𝒟k′​(𝒓)=ln⁡Pr⁡(𝒓|𝒟k)Pr⁡(𝒓|𝒟k′),subscriptℒsubscript𝒟𝑘superscriptsubscript𝒟𝑘′𝒓Prconditional𝒓subscript𝒟𝑘Prconditional𝒓superscriptsubscript𝒟𝑘′\mathcal{L}_{\mathcal{D}_{k},\mathcal{D}_{k}^{\prime}}(\boldsymbol{r})=\ln\frac{\Pr(\boldsymbol{r}|\mathcal{D}_{k})}{\Pr(\boldsymbol{r}|\mathcal{D}_{k}^{\prime})}, (8)

i.e., the log-likelihood ratio of the neighboring datasets 𝒟ksubscript𝒟𝑘\mathcal{D}_{k} and 𝒟k′superscriptsubscript𝒟𝑘′\mathcal{D}_{k}^{\prime} satisfies

Pr⁡(|ℒ𝒟k,𝒟k′​(𝒓)|≤ϵ)≥1−δ.Prsubscriptℒsubscript𝒟𝑘superscriptsubscript𝒟𝑘′𝒓italic-ϵ1𝛿\Pr\left(|\mathcal{L}_{\mathcal{D}_{k},\mathcal{D}_{k}^{\prime}}(\boldsymbol{r})|\leq\epsilon\right)\geq 1-\delta. (9)

From (9), we can see that a lower ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon yields a higher privacy guarantee for the FL system.

To achieve the privacy level ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon, a common method is to add random perturbations to the signals. We thus uniformly assign the artificial noise 𝒏k,t=[𝒏k,tT​(1),…,𝒏k,tT​(I)]T∈ℂdsubscript𝒏𝑘𝑡superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝒏𝑘𝑡𝑇1…superscriptsubscript𝒏𝑘𝑡𝑇𝐼𝑇superscriptℂ𝑑\boldsymbol{n}_{k,t}\!=\![\boldsymbol{n}_{k,t}^{T}(1),\ldots,\boldsymbol{n}_{k,t}^{T}(I)]^{T}\!\in\!\mathbb{C}^{d} with 𝒏k,t​(i)∼𝒞​𝒩​(𝟎,σk,t2​(i)​𝑰e)similar-tosubscript𝒏𝑘𝑡𝑖𝒞𝒩0superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑘𝑡2𝑖subscript𝑰𝑒\boldsymbol{n}_{k,t}(i)\sim\mathcal{CN}(\boldsymbol{0},\sigma_{k,t}^{2}(i)\,\boldsymbol{I}_{e}) to each communication block in the t𝑡t-th learning round, yielding a noisy version of the local update 𝒈k,tsubscript𝒈𝑘𝑡\boldsymbol{g}_{k,t}. Therefore, the pre-processed transmit signal of edge device k𝑘k is given as

𝒔k,t​(i)=Dk​𝒈k,t​(i)+𝒏k,t​(i).subscript𝒔𝑘𝑡𝑖subscript𝐷𝑘subscript𝒈𝑘𝑡𝑖subscript𝒏𝑘𝑡𝑖\boldsymbol{s}_{k,t}(i)=D_{k}\boldsymbol{g}_{k,t}(i)+\boldsymbol{n}_{k,t}(i). (10)

Notice that, for simplicity, we omit some procedures such as gradient clipping [45] which may preclude a large value of Dk​𝒈k,t​(i)subscript𝐷𝑘subscript𝒈𝑘𝑡𝑖D_{k}\boldsymbol{g}_{k,t}(i).

II-D Model Aggregation via Over-the-Air Computation

We leverage AirComp for fast model aggregation by exploiting signal superposition of a wireless multiple-access channel [20]. In AirComp, all edge devices transmit their local updates {𝒈k,t​(i)}k=1Ksuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝒈𝑘𝑡𝑖𝑘1𝐾\{\boldsymbol{g}_{k,t}(i)\}_{k=1}^{K} synchronously using the same time-frequency resources in the communication block, thereby achieving high communication efficiency [16].

Motivated by [46], based on the perfect CSI of each edge device, we design the block-based uniform-forcing transmit signal 𝒙k,t​(i)subscript𝒙𝑘𝑡𝑖\boldsymbol{x}_{k,t}(i) in the i𝑖i-th communication block of learning round t𝑡t as follows:

𝒙k,t​(i)=αk,t​(i)​𝒔k,t​(i)=ηt​(i)​(hk,t​(i))H|hk,t​(i)|2​𝒔k,t​(i),subscript𝒙𝑘𝑡𝑖subscript𝛼𝑘𝑡𝑖subscript𝒔𝑘𝑡𝑖subscript𝜂𝑡𝑖superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑘𝑡𝑖𝐻superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑘𝑡𝑖2subscript𝒔𝑘𝑡𝑖\boldsymbol{x}_{k,t}(i)=\alpha_{k,t}(i)\,\boldsymbol{s}_{k,t}(i)=\sqrt{\eta_{t}(i)}\,\frac{\,(h_{k,t}(i))^{H}}{|h_{k,t}(i)|^{2}}\,\boldsymbol{s}_{k,t}(i), (11)

where αk,t​(i)∈ℂsubscript𝛼𝑘𝑡𝑖ℂ\alpha_{k,t}(i)\in\mathbb{C} denotes the transmit scalar which is given by αk,t​(i)=ηt​(i)/hk,t​(i)subscript𝛼𝑘𝑡𝑖subscript𝜂𝑡𝑖subscriptℎ𝑘𝑡𝑖\alpha_{k,t}(i)=\sqrt{\eta_{t}(i)}/h_{k,t}(i) and ηt​(i)>0subscript𝜂𝑡𝑖0\sqrt{\eta_{t}(i)}>0 is the uniform power scaling factor. Given a maximum transmit power P0>0subscript𝑃00P_{0}>0 for all edge devices, we have the following power constraints in each communication block

𝔼​(‖𝒙k,t​(i)‖2)=𝔼​(‖αk,t​(i)​𝒔k,t​(i)‖2)≤P0,∀k,i,tformulae-sequence𝔼superscriptnormsubscript𝒙𝑘𝑡𝑖2𝔼superscriptnormsubscript𝛼𝑘𝑡𝑖subscript𝒔𝑘𝑡𝑖2subscript𝑃0for-all𝑘𝑖𝑡\mathbb{E}\left(\left|\left|\boldsymbol{x}_{k,t}(i)\right|\right|^{2}\right)=\mathbb{E}\left(\left|\left|\alpha_{k,t}(i)\boldsymbol{s}_{k,t}(i)\right|\right|^{2}\right)\leq P_{0},\,\forall k,i,t (12)

by taking the expectation over the additive Gaussian noise in (10). Note that, for each communication block, ηt​(i)subscript𝜂𝑡𝑖\eta_{t}(i) and 𝚯t​(i)subscript𝚯𝑡𝑖\boldsymbol{\Theta}_{t}(i) are elaborately designed by the edge server and broadcasted to the edge devices and RIS, which result in additional communication overheads.

Therefore, based on (10) and (11), the aggregated signal 𝒓t​(i)subscript𝒓𝑡𝑖\boldsymbol{r}_{t}(i) defined in (6) can be rewritten as

𝒓t​(i)=ηt​(i)​∑k=1KDk​𝒈k,t​(i)+ηt​(i)​∑k=1K𝒏k,t​(i)+𝒘t​(i).subscript𝒓𝑡𝑖subscript𝜂𝑡𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝐷𝑘subscript𝒈𝑘𝑡𝑖subscript𝜂𝑡𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝒏𝑘𝑡𝑖subscript𝒘𝑡𝑖\boldsymbol{r}_{t}(i)=\sqrt{\eta_{t}(i)}\sum_{k=1}^{K}D_{k}\boldsymbol{g}_{k,t}(i)+\sqrt{\eta_{t}(i)}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\boldsymbol{n}_{k,t}(i)+\boldsymbol{w}_{t}(i). (13)

Then, the edge server computes the estimated global update 𝒈^t​(i)subscript^𝒈𝑡𝑖\hat{\boldsymbol{g}}_{t}(i) by

𝒈^t​(i)=1K​D​ηt​(i)​Re​{𝒓t​(i)}=𝒈t​(i)+1K​D​∑k=1KRe​{𝒏k,t​(i)}+Re​{𝒘t​(i)}K​D​ηt​(i),subscript^𝒈𝑡𝑖1𝐾𝐷subscript𝜂𝑡𝑖Resubscript𝒓𝑡𝑖subscript𝒈𝑡𝑖1𝐾𝐷superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾Resubscript𝒏𝑘𝑡𝑖Resubscript𝒘𝑡𝑖𝐾𝐷subscript𝜂𝑡𝑖\begin{split}\hat{\boldsymbol{g}}_{t}(i)&=\frac{1}{KD\sqrt{\eta_{t}(i)}}\text{Re}\left\{\boldsymbol{r}_{t}(i)\right\}\\ &=\boldsymbol{g}_{t}(i)+\frac{1}{KD}\sum_{k=1}^{K}\text{Re}\{\boldsymbol{n}_{k,t}(i)\}+\frac{\text{Re}\left\{\boldsymbol{w}_{t}(i)\right\}}{KD\sqrt{\eta_{t}(i)}},\end{split} (14)

where 𝒈t​(i)=∑k=1K𝒈k,t​(i)/Ksubscript𝒈𝑡𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript𝒈𝑘𝑡𝑖𝐾\boldsymbol{g}_{t}(i)\!=\!\sum_{k=1}^{K}\boldsymbol{g}_{k,t}(i)/K. After I𝐼I rounds of model aggregation, the resulting 𝒈^t=[𝒈^tT​(1),…,𝒈^tT​(I)]Tsubscript^𝒈𝑡superscriptsuperscriptsubscript^𝒈𝑡𝑇1…superscriptsubscript^𝒈𝑡𝑇𝐼𝑇\hat{\boldsymbol{g}}_{t}\!=\![\hat{\boldsymbol{g}}_{t}^{T}(1),\ldots,\hat{\boldsymbol{g}}_{t}^{T}(I)]^{T} is an unbiased estimation of the true global gradient 𝒈t=[𝒈tT​(1),…,𝒈tT​(I)]Tsubscript𝒈𝑡superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝒈𝑡𝑇1…superscriptsubscript𝒈𝑡𝑇𝐼𝑇\boldsymbol{g}_{t}\!=\![\boldsymbol{g}_{t}^{T}(1),\ldots,\boldsymbol{g}_{t}^{T}(I)]^{T}. But the existence of the artificial noise and wireless channel noise leads to inevitable inaccuracy in 𝒈^tsubscript^𝒈𝑡\hat{\boldsymbol{g}}_{t}, which yields a trade-off between accuracy and privacy. In particular, the learning accuracy also depends on SNR, which is defined as the ratio of the maximum transmit power and the noise power in one communication block, i.e.,

SNR=P0e×N0,SNRsubscript𝑃0𝑒subscript𝑁0\text{SNR}=\frac{P_{0}}{e\times N_{0}}, (15)

where e×N0𝑒subscript𝑁0e\times N_{0} represents the channel noises power within one communication block.

Remark 1 (Symbol-level synchronization): Note that the AirComp-based aggregation rule relies on symbol-level synchronization among edge devices. To achieve this, a feasible technique is timing advance mechanism [47], which is widely used in 4G Long Term Evolution (LTE) and 5G New Radio (NR) systems. Specifically, consider the case when deploying AirComp in traditional Orthogonal Frequency Division Multiplexing (OFDM) systems, we note that 111 MHz synchronization bandwidth can limit the timing offset within 0.10.10.1 microseconds [48], which is shorter than the typical length of cyclic prefix (5 microseconds) in LTE systems. Thus, the symbol-level synchronization for AirComp is feasible.

Remark 2 (Limitation of uniform-forcing scalar): According to (11), channels inversion power control is adopted to achieve amplitude alignment at the edge server. However, due to the power constraint in (12), the uniform-forcing approach may be inefficient when some edge devices encounter deep fadings, which results in a small value of ηt​(i)subscript𝜂𝑡𝑖\eta_{t}(i). To overcome this issue, we can adopt the truncated-channel-inversion scheme [17], which allocates power to an edge device only if its channel gain exceeds a hard threshold. Besides, the deployment of RIS can also alleviate deep fadings by reconfiguring the wireless environment, which is elaborated in Section IV-A.

II-E Assumptions

We list several widely used assumptions [22, 49] for theoretical analysis of differentially private FL systems.

Assumption 1.

(Strong convexity) The global loss function F​(𝜽)𝐹𝜽F(\boldsymbol{\theta}) is strongly convex with parameter μ𝜇\mu, i.e.,

F​(𝜽)≥F​(𝜽′)+∇F​(𝜽′)T​(𝜽−𝜽′)+μ2​‖𝜽−𝜽′‖2,∀𝜽,𝜽′.𝐹𝜽𝐹superscript𝜽′∇𝐹superscriptsuperscript𝜽′𝑇𝜽superscript𝜽′𝜇2superscriptnorm𝜽superscript𝜽′2for-all𝜽superscript𝜽′F(\boldsymbol{\theta})\geq F(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\prime})+\nabla F(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\prime})^{T}(\boldsymbol{\theta}-\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\prime})+\frac{\mu}{2}||\boldsymbol{\theta}-\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\prime}||^{2},\;\forall\boldsymbol{\theta},\,\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\prime}. (16)
Assumption 2.

(Smoothness) The global loss function F​(𝜽)𝐹𝜽F(\boldsymbol{\theta}) is Lipschitz continuous with parameter L𝐿L, i.e.,

F​(𝜽)≤F​(𝜽′)+∇F​(𝜽′)T​(𝜽−𝜽′)+L2​‖𝜽−𝜽′‖2,∀𝜽,𝜽′,𝐹𝜽𝐹superscript𝜽′∇𝐹superscriptsuperscript𝜽′𝑇𝜽superscript𝜽′𝐿2superscriptnorm𝜽superscript𝜽′2for-all𝜽superscript𝜽′F(\boldsymbol{\theta})\leq F(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\prime})+\nabla F(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\prime})^{T}(\boldsymbol{\theta}-\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\prime})+\frac{L}{2}||\boldsymbol{\theta}-\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\prime}||^{2},\;\forall\boldsymbol{\theta},\,\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\prime},

which implies the following inequality:

‖∇F​(𝜽)−∇F​(𝜽′)‖≤L​‖𝜽−𝜽′‖,∀𝜽,𝜽′∈ℝd.formulae-sequencenorm∇𝐹𝜽∇𝐹superscript𝜽′𝐿norm𝜽superscript𝜽′for-all𝜽superscript𝜽′superscriptℝ𝑑||\nabla F(\boldsymbol{\theta})-\nabla F(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\prime})||\leq L||\boldsymbol{\theta}-\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\prime}||,\;\forall\boldsymbol{\theta},\,\boldsymbol{\theta}^{\prime}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}.
Assumption 3.

(Block gradient bound) In any learning round t𝑡t, for any training data sample (𝒙,y)𝒙𝑦(\boldsymbol{x},y), the sample-wise loss function is upper bounded by a given constant γtsubscript𝛾𝑡\gamma_{t}, i.e.,

‖∇f​(𝒙,y;𝜽t)‖≤γt,∀t.norm∇𝑓𝒙𝑦subscript𝜽𝑡subscript𝛾𝑡for-all𝑡\left|\left|\nabla f\left(\boldsymbol{x},y;\boldsymbol{\theta}_{t}\right)\right|\right|\leq\gamma_{t},\;\forall t. (17)

Based on triangular inequality, for edge device k𝑘k, there always exists a constant ζk,t​(i)≤γtsubscript𝜁𝑘𝑡𝑖subscript𝛾𝑡\zeta_{k,t}(i)\leq\gamma_{t} satisfying ‖𝒈k,t​(i)‖≤ζk,t​(i)normsubscript𝒈𝑘𝑡𝑖subscript𝜁𝑘𝑡𝑖\left|\left|\boldsymbol{g}_{k,t}(i)\right|\right|\leq\zeta_{k,t}(i).

III Performance Analysis and System Optimization

In this section, we shall analyze the convergence behavior of the RIS-enabled FL system and show the key component of the privacy-preserving mechanism. We then provide the system optimization formulation to model the dilemma between privacy and accuracy.

III-A Convergence Analysis

In the t𝑡t-th learning round, the edge server updates the global model based on the received signal 𝒓tsubscript𝒓𝑡\boldsymbol{r}_{t}. However, the fading channels {hk,t​(i)}subscriptℎ𝑘𝑡𝑖\{h_{k,t}(i)\} as well as the artificial noise {𝒏k,t​(i)}subscript𝒏𝑘𝑡𝑖\{\boldsymbol{n}_{k,t}(i)\} and AWGN {𝒘t​(i)}subscript𝒘𝑡𝑖\{\boldsymbol{w}_{t}(i)\} may severely degrade the learning performance. To characterize the convergence behavior of the RIS-enabled FL system, we leverage the expected value of the gap between the optimal value F∗superscript𝐹F^{*} and the iteration value F​(𝜽t)𝐹subscript𝜽𝑡F(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{t}) to measure the distortion over T𝑇T learning rounds, i.e., 𝔼​[F​(𝜽T+1)−F∗]𝔼delimited-[]𝐹subscript𝜽𝑇1superscript𝐹\mathbb{E}[F(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{T+1})-F^{*}]. Hence, given {ηt​(i),σk,t​(i)}subscript𝜂𝑡𝑖subscript𝜎𝑘𝑡𝑖\{\eta_{t}(i),\sigma_{k,t}(i)\}, we bound the average optimality gap in the following theorem.

Theorem 1.

Under Assumptions 1 and 2, given learning rate λ=1/L𝜆1𝐿\lambda=1/L, after T𝑇T learning iterations, the averaged optimality gap is upper bounded as

𝔼[F(𝜽T+1)]−F∗≤(1−μL)T[F(𝜽1)−F∗]+14​L×e(K​D)2​∑t=1T(1−μL)T−t​(∑k=1K∑i=1Iσk,t2​(i)+∑i=1IN0ηt​(i)).𝔼delimited-[]𝐹subscript𝜽𝑇1superscript𝐹superscript1𝜇𝐿𝑇delimited-[]𝐹subscript𝜽1superscript𝐹14𝐿𝑒superscript𝐾𝐷2superscriptsubscript𝑡1𝑇superscript1𝜇𝐿𝑇𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝐼superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑘𝑡2𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝐼subscript𝑁0subscript𝜂𝑡𝑖\begin{split}\mathbb{E}&\left[F\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{T+1}\right)\right]-F^{*}\leq\left(1-\frac{\mu}{L}\right)^{T}\left[F\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{1}\right)-F^{*}\right]+\frac{1}{4L}\times\\ &\;\;\frac{e}{(KD)^{2}}\sum_{t=1}^{T}\left(1-\frac{\mu}{L}\right)^{T-t}\left(\sum_{k=1}^{K}\sum_{i=1}^{I}\sigma_{k,t}^{2}(i)+\sum_{i=1}^{I}\frac{N_{0}}{\eta_{t}(i)}\right).\end{split} (18)
Proof.

Please refer to Appendix A. ∎

According to Theorem 1, we observe that the average optimality gap 𝔼​[F​(𝜽T+1)−F∗]𝔼delimited-[]𝐹subscript𝜽𝑇1superscript𝐹\mathbb{E}[F(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{T+1})\!-\!F^{*}] is upper bounded by two terms. The first term will converge to 00 as T𝑇T goes to infinity, while the second term in terms of {σk,t​(i),ηt​(i)}subscript𝜎𝑘𝑡𝑖subscript𝜂𝑡𝑖\{\sigma_{k,t}(i),\eta_{t}(i)\} cannot vanish due to the added artificial noise and wireless channel noise in each communication block. Besides, (18) is also related to 𝚯t​(i)subscript𝚯𝑡𝑖\boldsymbol{\Theta}_{t}(i) as the selection of ηt​(i)subscript𝜂𝑡𝑖\eta_{t}(i) depends on 𝚯t​(i)subscript𝚯𝑡𝑖\boldsymbol{\Theta}_{t}(i), which will be presented in Theorem 3.

III-B Privacy-Preserving Mechanism

We develop a privacy-preserving scheme based on DP to alleviate privacy concerns for edge devices. We assume that {ηt​(i),σk,t​(i),𝚯t​(i)}subscript𝜂𝑡𝑖subscript𝜎𝑘𝑡𝑖subscript𝚯𝑡𝑖\{\eta_{t}(i),\sigma_{k,t}(i),\boldsymbol{\Theta}_{t}(i)\} are fixed constants, as they do not reveal any information about the local datasets. Therefore, we only focus on the upload process from edge devices to the edge server. In the t𝑡t-th learning round, for edge device k𝑘k, the disclosed signals regarding its local dataset 𝒟ksubscript𝒟𝑘\mathcal{D}_{k} are {𝒈k,t​(i)}subscript𝒈𝑘𝑡𝑖\{\boldsymbol{g}_{k,t}(i)\} across I𝐼I blocks. We decouple the received signal 𝒓t​(i)subscript𝒓𝑡𝑖\boldsymbol{r}_{t}(i) as

𝒓t​(i)=ηt​(i)​Dk​𝒈k,t​(i)+ηt​(i)​∑j≠kDj​𝒈j,t​(i)+𝒒t​(i),subscript𝒓𝑡𝑖subscript𝜂𝑡𝑖subscript𝐷𝑘subscript𝒈𝑘𝑡𝑖subscript𝜂𝑡𝑖subscript𝑗𝑘subscript𝐷𝑗subscript𝒈𝑗𝑡𝑖subscript𝒒𝑡𝑖\boldsymbol{r}_{t}(i)=\sqrt{\eta_{t}(i)}D_{k}\boldsymbol{g}_{k,t}(i)+\sqrt{\eta_{t}(i)}\sum_{j\neq k}D_{j}\boldsymbol{g}_{j,t}(i)+\boldsymbol{q}_{t}(i), (19)

where

𝒒t​(i)=ηt​(i)​∑j=1K𝒏j,t​(i)+𝒘t​(i).subscript𝒒𝑡𝑖subscript𝜂𝑡𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝐾subscript𝒏𝑗𝑡𝑖subscript𝒘𝑡𝑖\boldsymbol{q}_{t}(i)=\sqrt{\eta_{t}(i)}\sum_{j=1}^{K}\boldsymbol{n}_{j,t}(i)+\boldsymbol{w}_{t}(i). (20)

In (19), the first term is the disclosed signal concerning 𝒟ksubscript𝒟𝑘\mathcal{D}_{k}, the second term is independent of edge device k𝑘k, and the third term 𝒒t​(i)subscript𝒒𝑡𝑖\boldsymbol{q}_{t}(i) is Gaussian noise. We observe that the privacy-preserving disturbance in (20) includes the added artificial noise and the inherent channel noise. Besides, all update messages, i.e., the first and second terms in (19), enjoy the same privacy protection provided by 𝒒t​(i)subscript𝒒𝑡𝑖\boldsymbol{q}_{t}(i). For notational ease, let 𝒒t=[𝒒tT​(1),…,𝒒tT​(I)]Tsubscript𝒒𝑡superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝒒𝑡𝑇1…superscriptsubscript𝒒𝑡𝑇𝐼𝑇\boldsymbol{q}_{t}=[\boldsymbol{q}_{t}^{T}(1),\ldots,\boldsymbol{q}_{t}^{T}(I)]^{T} denote the effective noise to ensure privacy for the transmission of {𝒈j,t}j=1Ksuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝒈𝑗𝑡𝑗1𝐾\{\boldsymbol{g}_{j,t}\}_{j=1}^{K} in the t𝑡t-th learning round.

For edge device k𝑘k, its privacy level (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta) depends on the sensitivity of the disclosed noise-free function regarding its local dataset. We first recall the definition of l2subscript𝑙2l_{2}-sensitivity [30].

Definition 2.

Let ℳℳ\mathcal{M} be an arbitrary mechanism on the transmitted signals. The l2subscript𝑙2l_{2}-sensitivity ΔΔ\Delta is defined as the maximum difference of the outputs from two neighboring datasets 𝒟ksubscript𝒟𝑘\mathcal{D}_{k} and 𝒟k′superscriptsubscript𝒟𝑘′\mathcal{D}_{k}^{\prime}, i.e.,

Δ=max𝒟k,𝒟k′‖ℳ​(𝒟k)−ℳ​(𝒟k′)‖2.Δsubscriptsubscript𝒟𝑘superscriptsubscript𝒟𝑘′subscriptnormℳsubscript𝒟𝑘ℳsuperscriptsubscript𝒟𝑘′2\Delta=\mathop{\max}\limits_{\mathcal{D}_{k},\mathcal{D}_{k}^{\prime}}\left|\left|\mathcal{M}\left(\mathcal{D}_{k}\right)-\mathcal{M}\left(\mathcal{D}_{k}^{\prime}\right)\right|\right|_{2}. (21)

Recalling that the first term in (19) is the only disclosed function concerning 𝒟ksubscript𝒟𝑘\mathcal{D}_{k}. Let 𝒖k,tsubscript𝒖𝑘𝑡\boldsymbol{u}_{k,t} denote the difference between the outputs from two neighboring datasets 𝒟ksubscript𝒟𝑘\mathcal{D}_{k} and 𝒟k′superscriptsubscript𝒟𝑘′\mathcal{D}_{k}^{\prime}, which is given by

𝒖k,t=[hk,t​(1)​αk,t​(1)​Δ​𝒈k,tT​(1),…,hk,t​(I)​αk,t​(I)​Δ​𝒈k,tT​(I)]T,subscript𝒖𝑘𝑡superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑘𝑡1subscript𝛼𝑘𝑡1Δsuperscriptsubscript𝒈𝑘𝑡𝑇1…subscriptℎ𝑘𝑡𝐼subscript𝛼𝑘𝑡𝐼Δsuperscriptsubscript𝒈𝑘𝑡𝑇𝐼𝑇\boldsymbol{u}_{k,t}\!=\![h_{k,t}(1)\alpha_{k,t}(1)\Delta\boldsymbol{g}_{k,t}^{T}(1),\!\ldots\!,\!h_{k,t}(I)\alpha_{k,t}(I)\Delta\boldsymbol{g}_{k,t}^{T}(I)]^{T}, (22)

where

Based on (24), the privacy constraint for all edge devices is given in the following theorem.

Proof.

Please refer to Appendix B. ∎

From Theorem 2, we emphasize that both the artificial noise and the receiver noise contribute to the privacy guarantee. Besides, based on (26), ξtsubscript𝜉𝑡\xi_{t} represents a lower bound of the weakest privacy-preserving perturbation (i.e., the lowest effective noise power) across I𝐼I communication blocks in the t𝑡t-th learning round. Furthermore, the privacy guarantee is related to the joint effect of ξtsubscript𝜉𝑡\xi_{t} and the maximum transmit power scalar ηt​(i)subscript𝜂𝑡𝑖\eta_{t}(i) among I𝐼I communication blocks. We also notice that the relationship between the privacy constraint and the phase-shift matrix 𝚯t​(i)subscript𝚯𝑡𝑖\boldsymbol{\Theta}_{t}(i) is similar to Theorem 1.

III-C System Optimization

To design the RIS-enabled FL system, we shall propose to minimize the optimality gap in (18) while satisfying the privacy and the maximum transmit power constraints given in (25) and (12), respectively, across T𝑇T learning rounds. Specifically, given the privacy level (ϵ,δ)italic-ϵ𝛿(\epsilon,\delta), we jointly optimize {σk,t​(i),𝚯t​(i),ηt​(i),ξt}subscript𝜎𝑘𝑡𝑖subscript𝚯𝑡𝑖subscript𝜂𝑡𝑖subscript𝜉𝑡\{\sigma_{k,t}(i),\boldsymbol{\Theta}_{t}(i),\eta_{t}(i),\xi_{t}\} in each communication block. Based on (10), (11) and (12), we obtain the power constraints,

𝔼​(‖𝒙k,t‖2)​≤(a)​ηt​(i)|hk,t​(i)|2​[Dk2​ζk,t2​(i)+e​σk,t2​(i)]≤P0,∀i,k,t,𝔼superscriptnormsubscript𝒙𝑘𝑡2𝑎subscript𝜂𝑡𝑖superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑘𝑡𝑖2delimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝐷𝑘2superscriptsubscript𝜁𝑘𝑡2𝑖𝑒superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑘𝑡2𝑖subscript𝑃0for-all𝑖𝑘𝑡\mathbb{E}\left(\left|\left|\boldsymbol{x}_{k,t}\right|\right|^{2}\right)\overset{(a)}{\leq}\frac{\eta_{t}(i)}{|h_{k,t}(i)|^{2}}[D_{k}^{2}\zeta_{k,t}^{2}(i)+e\sigma_{k,t}^{2}(i)]\leq P_{0},\,\forall i,k,t,

where (a) comes from the fact ‖𝒈k,t​(i)‖≤ζk,t​(i)normsubscript𝒈𝑘𝑡𝑖subscript𝜁𝑘𝑡𝑖||\boldsymbol{g}_{k,t}(i)||\leq\zeta_{k,t}(i) in Assumption 3, along with the triangular inequality.

Unfortunately, due to the non-convexity of the privacy and power constraints, and the nonconvex unimodular constraints of the phase shifts at RIS, problem 𝒫𝒫\mathscr{P} is highly intractable and computationally challenging.

IV A Two-Step Alternating Low-Rank Optimization Framework

In this section, we propose a two-step alternating minimization framework for solving problem 𝒫𝒫\mathscr{P}. Specifically, the transmit power scalar ηt​(i)subscript𝜂𝑡𝑖\eta_{t}(i) and artificial noise σk,t​(i)subscript𝜎𝑘𝑡𝑖\sigma_{k,t}(i) at each edge device, as well as the phase-shift matrix 𝚯t​(i)subscript𝚯𝑡𝑖\boldsymbol{\Theta}_{t}(i) at the RIS are optimized in an alternative manner until the algorithm converges.

IV-A Co-Design of Artificial Noise and Power Scalar

The main idea of this framework is to alternately optimize {ηt​(i),σk,t​(i),𝚯t​(i),ξt}subscript𝜂𝑡𝑖subscript𝜎𝑘𝑡𝑖subscript𝚯𝑡𝑖subscript𝜉𝑡\{\eta_{t}(i),\sigma_{k,t}(i),\boldsymbol{\Theta}_{t}(i),\xi_{t}\} in T𝑇T learning rounds. Note that problem 𝒫𝒫\mathscr{P} is a non-causal setting where parameters {𝒉k,tr​(i),𝒎t​(i),hk,td​(i),ζk,t​(i),γt}superscriptsubscript𝒉𝑘𝑡𝑟𝑖subscript𝒎𝑡𝑖superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑘𝑡𝑑𝑖subscript𝜁𝑘𝑡𝑖subscript𝛾𝑡\{\boldsymbol{h}_{k,t}^{r}(i),\boldsymbol{m}_{t}(i),h_{k,t}^{d}(i),\zeta_{k,t}(i),\gamma_{t}\} need to be known in advance, which will be discussed in Section VI-C.

Given the phase-shift matrix 𝚯t​(i)subscript𝚯𝑡𝑖\boldsymbol{\Theta}_{t}(i), problem 𝒫𝒫\mathscr{P} is reduced to problem 𝒫1subscript𝒫1\mathscr{P}_{1} as follows:

Please refer to Appendix C. ∎

From Theorem 3, the power of artificial noise becomes zero, which indicates that the additive channel noise in model aggregation serves as an inherent privacy-preserving mechanism to guarantee DP levels for each edge device [34]. Besides, as shown in Fig. 4, three cases characterize the learning accuracy of the FL system. Essentially, the power allocation scheme, i.e., the selection of ηt​(i)subscript𝜂𝑡𝑖\eta_{t}(i) under different ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon causes the difference in learning accuracy. To make it precise, Fig. 4 illustrates this process in one learning round. Specifically, two power alignment schemes are developed for comparison, where one represents the maximum transmit power concerning privacy requirement {ϵ,τt}italic-ϵsubscript𝜏𝑡\{\epsilon,\tau_{t}\}, and the other indicates the case without privacy, i.e., the Minimum column in Fig. 4. We note that τtsubscript𝜏𝑡\tau_{t}, which represents the impact of ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon across I𝐼I communication blocks, is the key component of Theorem 3. Concretely, τtsubscript𝜏𝑡\tau_{t} indicates the number of communication blocks restricted by privacy in one learning round, i.e., the number of yellow bars in Fig. 4. Consequently, different ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon results in a different selection of τtsubscript𝜏𝑡\tau_{t}, yielding the following three cases:

  • •

    Case (a): Due to the extremely strict privacy level, all communication blocks in this case are restricted by privacy, i.e., τt=Isubscript𝜏𝑡𝐼\tau_{t}=I.

  • •

    Case (b): In this case, several communication blocks are restricted by privacy while others are limited by transmit power, i.e., τt∈[I]subscript𝜏𝑡delimited-[]𝐼\tau_{t}\in[I]. Besides, cases (a) and (b) must satisfy the equality in (27b), which is achieved by adaptively selecting {β,τt}𝛽subscript𝜏𝑡\{\beta,\tau_{t}\} through enumeration.

  • •

    Case (c): In this case, due to the quite loose privacy level, all communication blocks are limited by the transmit power constraints, i.e., τt=0subscript𝜏𝑡0\tau_{t}=0.

We reveal the benefits achieved by RIS to the above three cases. Due to the reconfigurable capability of RIS, we note that the RIS-enabled FL system is able to establish better channel conditions compared to the FL systems without RIS. Besides, according to (32) and (34), the RIS-enabled FL system can enjoy higher transmit power and enhance the power of received signals at the edge server, thereby resulting in high learning accuracy. However, when the privacy level is strict, i.e., Case (a), the learning accuracy is restricted by privacy and cannot be improved by RIS. We will further explore the significant impacts brought by RIS on the learning accuracy via simulations in Section V.

However, the resulting problem 𝒫2.3subscript𝒫2.3\mathscr{P}_{2.3} is still nonconvex due to the rank-one constraints in (38d). Fortunately, a feasible solution to this problem can be generated by simply dropping the rank-one constraints via the SDR technique [51]. The resulting SDP problem can be solved efficiently by existing convex optimization solvers such as CVX [52]. Although the Gaussian randomization technique in SDR may generate a suboptimal solution, we can still observe that a significant learning performance gain of the RIS-enabled FL system can be achieved through numerical experiments.

Without causing confusion, we omit parameter i𝑖i for notational ease, e.g., 𝚯t​(i)subscript𝚯𝑡𝑖\boldsymbol{\Theta}_{t}(i) as 𝚯tsubscript𝚯𝑡\boldsymbol{\Theta}_{t}. We present the two-step iterative framework in Algorithm 1 for solving problem 𝒫𝒫\mathscr{P}. The computational cost of the proposed algorithm consists of solving a sequence of search programs for 𝒫1subscript𝒫1\mathscr{P}_{1} and SDR programs [51] for 𝒫2subscript𝒫2\mathscr{P}_{2}. From the complexity analysis of typical interior-point method, the worst-case complexity of Algorithm 1 is obtained as 𝒪(JITmax{K,N+1}4N+1log2(1/o))\mathcal{O}\left(JIT\max\{K,N+1\}^{4}\sqrt{N+1}\log_{2}(1/o)\right), where o>0𝑜0o>0 denotes the solution accuracy of SDR.

IV-C Discussion on the Causal Approximation

Based on the above observations, Algorithm 1 solves the nonconvex problem 𝒫𝒫\mathscr{P} with the knowledge of all channel responses {hk,td​(i),𝒎t​(i),𝒉k,tr​(i)}superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑘𝑡𝑑𝑖subscript𝒎𝑡𝑖superscriptsubscript𝒉𝑘𝑡𝑟𝑖\{h_{k,t}^{d}(i),\boldsymbol{m}_{t}(i),\boldsymbol{h}_{k,t}^{r}(i)\} and local gradient information {ζk,t​(i),γt}subscript𝜁𝑘𝑡𝑖subscript𝛾𝑡\{\zeta_{k,t}(i),\gamma_{t}\}, yielding an impractical non-causal system. We thus present some feasible prediction methods to approximate this non-causal system.

At the beginning of the training process, we need to address the following two questions for our proposed scheme:

  • •

    How to approximate the future gradient information?

  • •

    How to predict the future channel responses?

The first question aims at providing upper bounds for the l2subscript𝑙2l_{2}-sensitivity defined in (23) and the local gradients. To this end, there exist multiple adaptive methods for practical use, such as the L𝐿L-Lipschitz based technique [53, 54], and the adaptive clipping method [55] with a well-designed critical threshold based on the current gradients.

For the second question, this is essentially related to wireless channel prediction. To estimate channels accurately, many promising methods have been proposed. For instance, the authors in [34] specialized an accumulated mechanism where the future channel responses are assumed to be consistent with the current ones. But this assumption fails to exploit the correlation among channel blocks. To explore the inherent relationship between each communication block, several prediction techniques have been developed in [56, 57], including the Gauss-Markov process channel modeling method [58] and Wiener or Kalman filtering based approach [59, 58]. Besides, the deep learning methods turn out to be powerful to improve channel prediction accuracy [60, 61, 62]. We thus leave the design of effective casual models as our future work.

V Simulation Results

In this section, we present the simulation results to demonstrate the advantages of the RIS-enabled FL systems. Besides, the effectiveness of our proposed two-step alternating minimization framework will also be illustrated. Simulations are conducted using Matlab R2021b and the code is available at https://github.com/MengCongWo/FL_Privacy_blockcrossing.

V-A Simulation Settings

As for the definitions of γtsubscript𝛾𝑡\gamma_{t} and ζk,t​(i)subscript𝜁𝑘𝑡𝑖\zeta_{k,t}(i), we use the simple upper bounds as in [34, Section V-A]. Furthermore, we use the normalized optimality gap defined as [F​(𝜽T+1)−F​(𝜽∗)]/F​(𝜽∗)delimited-[]𝐹subscript𝜽𝑇1𝐹superscript𝜽𝐹superscript𝜽[F(\boldsymbol{\theta}_{T+1})-F(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{*})]/F(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{*}) to measure the learning accuracy.

The wireless channels are assumed to suffer from Rice fading [24], and the channel coefficients are given by

ϱ=κ1+κ​ϱL​o​S+11+κ​ϱN​L​o​S,bold-italic-ϱ𝜅1𝜅subscriptbold-italic-ϱ𝐿𝑜𝑆11𝜅subscriptbold-italic-ϱ𝑁𝐿𝑜𝑆\boldsymbol{\varrho}=\sqrt{\frac{\kappa}{1+\kappa}}\boldsymbol{\varrho}_{LoS}+\sqrt{\frac{1}{1+\kappa}}\boldsymbol{\varrho}_{NLoS}, (41)

where κ𝜅\kappa represents the Rician factor, ϱL​o​Ssubscriptbold-italic-ϱ𝐿𝑜𝑆\boldsymbol{\varrho}_{LoS} denotes the deterministic line-of-sight (LoS) component, and ϱN​L​o​Ssubscriptbold-italic-ϱ𝑁𝐿𝑜𝑆\boldsymbol{\varrho}_{NLoS} denotes the non-line-of-sight (NLoS) component. For simplicity, we set ϱL​o​S=1subscriptbold-italic-ϱ𝐿𝑜𝑆1\boldsymbol{\varrho}_{LoS}=1 and generate ϱN​L​o​Ssubscriptbold-italic-ϱ𝑁𝐿𝑜𝑆\boldsymbol{\varrho}_{NLoS} by autoregressive (AR) scheme, which is defined as

ϱN​L​o​S​(i)=ρ​ϱN​L​o​S​(i−1)+1−ρ2​ϑ​(i),subscriptbold-italic-ϱ𝑁𝐿𝑜𝑆𝑖𝜌subscriptbold-italic-ϱ𝑁𝐿𝑜𝑆𝑖11superscript𝜌2bold-italic-ϑ𝑖\boldsymbol{\varrho}_{NLoS}(i)=\rho\boldsymbol{\varrho}_{NLoS}(i-1)+\sqrt{1-\rho^{2}}\boldsymbol{\vartheta}(i), (42)

where ρ𝜌\rho denotes the correlation coefficient and ϑ​(i)bold-italic-ϑ𝑖\boldsymbol{\vartheta}(i) is drawn based on an innovation process satisfying ϑ​(i)∼𝒩​(𝟎,𝑰)similar-tobold-italic-ϑ𝑖𝒩0𝑰\boldsymbol{\vartheta}(i)\sim\mathcal{N}(\boldsymbol{0},\boldsymbol{I}). Hence, the channel coefficients in the i𝑖i-th communication block of learning round t𝑡t are given by 𝒎t​(i)=ϱI​Bsubscript𝒎𝑡𝑖subscriptbold-italic-ϱ𝐼𝐵\boldsymbol{m}_{t}(i)=\boldsymbol{\varrho}_{IB}, 𝒉k,tr​(i)=ϱD​Isuperscriptsubscript𝒉𝑘𝑡𝑟𝑖subscriptbold-italic-ϱ𝐷𝐼\boldsymbol{h}_{k,t}^{r}(i)=\boldsymbol{\varrho}_{DI}, and hk,td​(i)=ϱD​Bsuperscriptsubscriptℎ𝑘𝑡𝑑𝑖subscriptitalic-ϱ𝐷𝐵h_{k,t}^{d}(i)=\varrho_{DB}, whose Rician factors are given by κI​Bsubscript𝜅𝐼𝐵\kappa_{IB}, κD​Isubscript𝜅𝐷𝐼\kappa_{DI}, and κD​Bsubscript𝜅𝐷𝐵\kappa_{DB}, respectively. The parameter ρ𝜌\rho is set to 111 for simplicity since ρ𝜌\rho has no discernible effect on the performance in the case where perfect CSI is available for all edge devices.

Under the above simulation settings, we mainly compare the learning accuracy under the following three RIS schemes:

  • •

    RIS-enabled FL system with DP: In this scheme, Algorithm 1 is applied to solve problem 𝒫𝒫\mathscr{P}.

  • •

    RIS-enabled FL system without DP: In this scheme, we remove the privacy constraints for the baseline without DP, i.e., only the second term in (32) exists.

  • •

    FL system without RIS: In this scheme, we set 𝚯t​(i)=𝟎subscript𝚯𝑡𝑖0\boldsymbol{\Theta}_{t}(i)=\boldsymbol{0} for the baseline without RIS but with DP [34].

The system parameters used in the simulations are summarized in Table II for reference. We also simulate a practical IoT-based affective computing FL scenario [63] with high dimensional and nonconvex settings, which will be presented in Section V-C.

V-B Learning Accuracy under Different Conditions

To investigate the improvements of learning accuracy achieved by RIS, we compare the learning accuracy of the three RIS schemes based on the ridge regression model from five aspects: privacy levels ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon, SNR levels, the number of learning rounds T𝑇T, the impact of system heterogeneity r𝑟r, and the number of RIS elements N𝑁N. We also simulate a high dimensional setting based on the CIFAR-10 dataset and a nonconvex setting based on the MNIST dataset.

We first illustrate the relationship between learning accuracy and privacy level ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon in Fig. 8. As an extension of Fig. 4, we demonstrate that with the relaxation of privacy level, i.e., for larger values of ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon, the RIS-enabled FL system achieves a higher learning performance gain compared to the case without RIS which is restricted by unfavorable wireless channel propagations. Instead, RIS has no impact on the learning performance when the privacy level is strict, i.e., the privacy field presented in Theorem 3. Besides, comparing the learning accuracy of the RIS-enabled FL system with DP and the case without DP, we note that the privacy guarantee is achieved at the expense of losing learning accuracy, i.e., higher privacy (smaller value of ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon) indicates lower learning accuracy.

In Fig. 8, we focus on the learning accuracy of the RIS-enabled FL systems in the noisy wireless environment, i.e., various levels of SNR. It shows that, with the increase of SNR, the DP-restricted schemes achieve the same learning accuracy, i.e., around 4×10−34superscript1034\times 10^{-3}, under the same privacy and power constraints. Besides, we note that the RIS-enabled FL systems achieve a notable improvement in learning accuracy compared to the FL systems without RIS, especially when SNR is low. This indicates that the RIS-enabled FL systems are more adaptable to noisy wireless channels. Furthermore, Fig. 8 shows that the RIS-enabled FL system with DP achieves close accuracy with the case without DP when SNR<20SNR20\text{SNR}<20. This indicates that privacy guarantee can be ensured freely [34].

The impact brought by the number of learning rounds T𝑇T or total communication blocks on the learning accuracy is illustrated in Fig. 8, where the oscillation comes from the newly introduced wireless noise in each communication block. We observe that without considering the effect of noise, the number of learning rounds T𝑇T has no evident effect on the accuracy after running enough number of training rounds for gradient descent due to the adaptive selection of {β,τt}𝛽subscript𝜏𝑡\{\beta,\tau_{t}\} performed in Theorem 3. To make it precise, β𝛽\beta can flexibly adjust the selection of ηt​(i)subscript𝜂𝑡𝑖\eta_{t}(i) to ensure that it satisfies all constraints with the increase of T𝑇T. Moreover, the RIS-enabled FL systems achieve higher accuracy and better robustness to the newly added wireless channel noise.

Fig. 8 shows the learning accuracy of three RIS schemes among various degrees of system heterogeneity r𝑟r. For simplicity, one edge device is assigned more data points while the rest are evenly distributed to the remaining edge devices [34]. Simulation results show the negative influence brought by the high-heterogenous system on accuracy. Besides, compared to the FL systems without RIS, the RIS-enabled FL systems are more robust due to the interaction between channel condition and system heterogeneity in (32). Furthermore, Fig. 8 serves as a promising result for the design of anti-heterogeneous FL systems by deploying RIS to weaken heterogeneity.

Fig. 9 illustrates the impacts of the number of reflecting elements N𝑁N at RIS on the learning accuracy under three fields presented in Theorem 3. From Fig. 9, we verify that the learning accuracy cannot be significantly improved when the privacy level is extremely strict (privacy field), while the benefits of deploying RIS emerge when the privacy level is relaxing. Besides, we note that with the increase of N𝑁N, the reconfigurable capability of RIS enhances, yielding high learning accuracy. However, due to the existence of privacy constraints, this improvement of learning accuracy may slow down when N𝑁N becomes large.

Fig. 11 and Fig. 11 show the learning accuracy of three RIS schemes on the MNIST and CIFAR-10 datasets, respectively. Specifically, we train a logistic regression model on the CIFAR-10 dataset for high dimensional settings and a neural network on MNIST for nonconvex settings. The neural network model parameter 𝜽𝜽\boldsymbol{\theta} with dimension d=79510𝑑79510d\!=\!79510 is comprised of the first-layer parameter 𝑾1∈ℝ100×785subscript𝑾1superscriptℝ100785\boldsymbol{W}_{1}\!\in\!\mathbb{R}^{100\times 785} and the second-layer parameter 𝑾2∈ℝ10×101subscript𝑾2superscriptℝ10101\boldsymbol{W}_{2}\!\in\!\mathbb{R}^{10\times 101}. For high-privacy and noisy environment, we reset the privacy level ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon to be 101010, the SNR level to be 5​dB5dB5\,\text{dB}, the number of communication blocks in one learning round I𝐼I to be 101010, and the Rice factor of ϱD​Bsubscriptbold-italic-ϱ𝐷𝐵\boldsymbol{\varrho}_{DB} to be 00 (Rayleigh channel). Fig. 11 and Fig. 11 indicate that the RIS-enabled FL system with DP enjoys higher accuracy and better robustness to the wireless channel noise compared to the FL system without RIS. Besides, the accuracy of the RIS-enabled FL system is close to the case without DP. Furthermore, we can observe that our proposed methods can achieve good performance even for nonconvex learning tasks.

V-C Differentially Private FL for Wearable IoT-Based Biomedical Monitoring

Driven by the massive amounts of biomedical data generated from widespread IoT edge devices, affective computing has become a field of interest in biomedical informatics [64]. Affective computing is a promising technique that recognizes a person’s emotional state based on the physiological signals and images, e.g., photoplethysmogram (PPG) based heart activity, to detect the link between physical health and emotional states. To integrate distributed health data analysis and privacy protection, the authors in [63] established a practical IoT-based wearable biomedical monitoring scenario and provided a first attempt on the application of privacy-preserving FL to IoT-based affective computing. Specifically, 32 public school teachers from Turkey participated in the IoT-based stress detection experiment, where each teacher was required to wear wrist-worn wearable IoT devices and experience three different emotional sessions (baseline, lecture, exam). After each session, the heart activity features collected by wearable IoT devices and the mental state report from each teacher were gathered to construct the stress detection dataset. Besides, the collected data is distributed unevenly across K=26𝐾26K=26 private edge devices, which are orchestrated by an edge server to collaboratively train a global stress detection model. Inspired by this, we simulate a practical wireless IoT-based stress detection FL scenario with DP guarantees to test the learning performance of three RIS schemes.

We train a neural network on the stress detection dataset whose model parameter 𝜽𝜽\boldsymbol{\theta} with dimension d=12002𝑑12002d=12002 consists of the the first-layer parameter 𝑾1∈ℝ100×17subscript𝑾1superscriptℝ10017\boldsymbol{W}_{1}\in\mathbb{R}^{100\times 17}, the second-layer parameter 𝑾2∈ℝ100×101subscript𝑾2superscriptℝ100101\boldsymbol{W}_{2}\in\mathbb{R}^{100\times 101} and the third-layer parameter 𝑾3∈ℝ2×101subscript𝑾3superscriptℝ2101\boldsymbol{W}_{3}\in\mathbb{R}^{2\times 101}. The classification accuracy on the stress detection dataset under different levels of privacy and SNR is presented in Table III. It can be observed that the RIS-enabled FL system with DP is capable of outperforming the FL system without RIS in terms of classification accuracy and robustness to wireless noise. The RIS-enabled system with DP can also achieve similar performance compared with the system without DP.

VI Conclusions

In this paper, we developed an RIS-enable differentially private FL system by leveraging the reconfigurability of channel propagation via RIS and the property of waveform superposition via AirComp. We theoretically characterized the convergence behavior of the over-the-air FL algorithm, for which a system optimization problem was established to achieve better learning accuracy under the privacy and transmit power constraints. We further proposed a two-step low-rank optimization framework to minimize the learning optimality gap, by jointly optimizing the power allocation, artificial noise, and reflecting coefficients of RIS during the learning procedure. Through convergence analysis and system optimization, we revealed that the RIS-enabled FL system is able to achieve higher system SNR and boost the receive signal power, thereby improving learning accuracy performance while satisfying the privacy requirements. Numerical results also demonstrated that the proposed FL system can achieve higher learning accuracy and privacy than the benchmarks.

Appendix B Proof of Theorem 2

which indicate that at least one of ι~tisuperscriptsubscript~𝜄𝑡𝑖\widetilde{\iota}_{t}^{i} and φ~k,tisuperscriptsubscript~𝜑𝑘𝑡𝑖\widetilde{\varphi}_{k,t}^{i} is greater than 00. Based on this, we mainly focus on the following three conditions and elaborate their optimality.

Power field: On the one hand, we first focus on a simple case where the inequality in (55b) strictly holds, i.e., the privacy constraint is not dominant. Hence, according to complementary slackness condition, we immediately get

β~=u~ti=ι~ti=0,∀i,t.formulae-sequence~𝛽superscriptsubscript~𝑢𝑡𝑖superscriptsubscript~𝜄𝑡𝑖0for-all𝑖𝑡\widetilde{\beta}=\widetilde{u}_{t}^{i}=\widetilde{\iota}_{t}^{i}=0,\,\forall i,t. (57)

Furthermore, we have φ~k,t>0subscript~𝜑𝑘𝑡0\widetilde{\varphi}_{k,t}>0 based on (56a) which also implies a~k,ti=0superscriptsubscript~𝑎𝑘𝑡𝑖0\widetilde{a}_{k,t}^{i}=0. Hence, the power constraint (55d) becomes the unique one that restricts the learning accuracy. Based on this, we arrive at the unique optimal solution in this case, i.e.,

b~ti=1P0​maxk∈[K]​D2​ζk,t2​(i)|hk,t​(i)|2.superscriptsubscript~𝑏𝑡𝑖1subscript𝑃0𝑘delimited-[]𝐾superscript𝐷2superscriptsubscript𝜁𝑘𝑡2𝑖superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑘𝑡𝑖2\widetilde{b}_{t}^{i}=\frac{1}{P_{0}}\underset{k\in[K]}{\max}\frac{D^{2}\zeta_{k,t}^{2}(i)}{\;|h_{k,t}(i)|^{2}}. (58)

On the other hand, we turn to the difficult multi-solution case where the privacy constraint (55b) is stringent with β~≠0~𝛽0\widetilde{\beta}\neq 0, which results in the following equality:

∑t=1T4​γt2dt−ℛd​p=0.superscriptsubscript𝑡1𝑇4superscriptsubscript𝛾𝑡2subscript𝑑𝑡subscriptℛ𝑑𝑝0\sum_{t=1}^{T}\frac{4\gamma_{t}^{2}}{d_{t}}-\mathcal{R}_{dp}=0. (59)

Motivated by the previous condition, we set a~k,ti=0superscriptsubscript~𝑎𝑘𝑡𝑖0\widetilde{a}_{k,t}^{i}=0, which saves the communication and power resources of the edge server. Hence, we arrive at the following two conditions.

Privacy field: We first focus on the case where only the privacy constraint takes effect, which indicates (55d) strictly holds, i.e.,

b~t>1P0​maxi,k​D2​ζk,t2​(i)|hk,t​(i)|2,subscript~𝑏𝑡1subscript𝑃0𝑖𝑘superscript𝐷2superscriptsubscript𝜁𝑘𝑡2𝑖superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑘𝑡𝑖2\widetilde{b}_{t}>\frac{1}{P_{0}}\underset{i,k}{\max}\frac{D^{2}\zeta_{k,t}^{2}(i)}{\;|h_{k,t}(i)|^{2}}, (60)

yielding ψ~k,ti=0superscriptsubscript~𝜓𝑘𝑡𝑖0\widetilde{\psi}_{k,t}^{i}\!=\!0. Hence, based on (56b) and (56c), we obtain

u~ti=ι~ti=(1−μ/L)−t,∀i,t.formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript~𝑢𝑡𝑖superscriptsubscript~𝜄𝑡𝑖superscript1𝜇𝐿𝑡for-all𝑖𝑡\widetilde{u}_{t}^{i}=\widetilde{\iota}_{t}^{i}=(1-\mu/L)^{-t},\,\forall i,t. (61)

Besides, combining (56d) and complementary slackness condition, we further get

d~t=c~ti=N0​b~ti=2​γtI​(β~)12​(1−μL)t2,subscript~𝑑𝑡superscriptsubscript~𝑐𝑡𝑖subscript𝑁0superscriptsubscript~𝑏𝑡𝑖2subscript𝛾𝑡𝐼superscript~𝛽12superscript1𝜇𝐿𝑡2\widetilde{d}_{t}=\widetilde{c}_{t}^{i}=N_{0}\widetilde{b}_{t}^{i}=\frac{2\gamma_{t}}{\sqrt{I}}(\widetilde{\beta})^{\frac{1}{2}}\left(1-\frac{\mu}{L}\right)^{\frac{t}{2}}, (62)

which indicates b~tisuperscriptsubscript~𝑏𝑡𝑖\widetilde{b}_{t}^{i} remains constant during one learning round, and for short, we denote b~t=b~ti,∀isubscript~𝑏𝑡superscriptsubscript~𝑏𝑡𝑖for-all𝑖\widetilde{b}_{t}=\widetilde{b}_{t}^{i},\forall i. In summary, the optimal conditions of b~tsubscript~𝑏𝑡\widetilde{b}_{t} are given by (59), (60), and (62).

Privacy-power field: Now, we turn to analyze the case where the dual constraints of privacy and power take effect, i.e., there exist some c~ti≠d~tsuperscriptsubscript~𝑐𝑡𝑖subscript~𝑑𝑡\widetilde{c}_{t}^{i}\neq\widetilde{d}_{t} which lead to u~ti=ι~ti=0superscriptsubscript~𝑢𝑡𝑖superscriptsubscript~𝜄𝑡𝑖0\widetilde{u}_{t}^{i}=\widetilde{\iota}_{t}^{i}=0. Besides, from (56b), we can verify that there exist ψ~k,ti≠0superscriptsubscript~𝜓𝑘𝑡𝑖0\widetilde{\psi}_{k,t}^{i}\neq 0 based on the power constraints of all edge devices. Remarkably, b~tisuperscriptsubscript~𝑏𝑡𝑖\widetilde{b}_{t}^{i} remains constant across all edge devices in the i𝑖i-th communication block of learning round t𝑡t, so it must meet all power constraints and strictly satisfy a certain one, i.e.,

b~ti=1P0​max𝑘​D2​ζk,t2​(i)|hk,t​(i)|2.superscriptsubscript~𝑏𝑡𝑖1subscript𝑃0𝑘superscript𝐷2superscriptsubscript𝜁𝑘𝑡2𝑖superscriptsubscriptℎ𝑘𝑡𝑖2\widetilde{b}_{t}^{i}=\frac{1}{P_{0}}\underset{k}{\max}\frac{D^{2}\zeta_{k,t}^{2}(i)}{\;|h_{k,t}(i)|^{2}}. (63)

As for the other u~ti≠0superscriptsubscript~𝑢𝑡𝑖0\widetilde{u}_{t}^{i}\neq 0, we consider it as a generalized version of (61), i.e., some communication blocks are restricted by privacy while the others are power. For analytical ease, we introduce parameter τtsubscript𝜏𝑡\tau_{t} to represent the number of communication blocks limited by privacy in the t𝑡t-th learning round, i.e., u~k,ti≠0superscriptsubscript~𝑢𝑘𝑡𝑖0\widetilde{u}_{k,t}^{i}\!\neq\!0. Hence, (56d) can be reformulated as

τt​(1−μL)−t=4​γt2d~t2​β~.subscript𝜏𝑡superscript1𝜇𝐿𝑡4superscriptsubscript𝛾𝑡2superscriptsubscript~𝑑𝑡2~𝛽\tau_{t}\left(1-\frac{\mu}{L}\right)^{-t}=\frac{4\gamma_{t}^{2}}{\widetilde{d}_{t}^{2}}\widetilde{\beta}. (64)

For instance, if all communication blocks are restricted by privacy, τtsubscript𝜏𝑡\tau_{t} is set to I𝐼I which is the same as (62), i.e., Privacy field. Therefore, considering the above two cases, we arrive at the expected result by elaborately selecting τtsubscript𝜏𝑡\tau_{t} in each learning round t𝑡t and parameter β~~𝛽\widetilde{\beta} to strictly meet (59).

Finally, according to (53), we obtain the expected result. ∎
